user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketShutdown_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketShutdown_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_SocketShutdownMode_t Mode)
{
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *conn_impl;
    int32                           return_code;
    int                             how;

    conn_impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    /* Note that when called via the shared layer,
     * the "Mode" arg has already been checked/validated. */
    if (Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ)
    {
        how = SHUT_RD;
    }
    else if (Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE)
    {
        how = SHUT_WR;
    }
    else
    {
        how = SHUT_RDWR;
    }

    if (shutdown(conn_impl->fd, how) == 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketShutdown_Impl:
typedef enum
{
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_NONE           = 0, /**< @brief Reserved value, no effect */
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ      = 1, /**< @brief Disable future reading */
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE     = 2, /**< @brief Disable future writing */
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READWRITE = 3  /**< @brief Disable future reading or writing */
} OS_SocketShutdownMode_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
int32 OS_SocketShutdown(osal_id_t sock_id, OS_SocketShutdownMode_t Mode)
{
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;
    OS_object_token_t            token;
    int32                        return_code;

    /* Confirm that "Mode" is one of the 3 acceptable values */
    BUGCHECK(Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ || Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE ||
                 Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READWRITE,
             OS_ERR_INVALID_ARGUMENT);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sock_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, token);

        if (stream->socket_domain == OS_SocketDomain_INVALID)
        {
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE;
        }
        else if (stream->socket_type == OS_SocketType_STREAM && (stream->stream_state & OS_STREAM_STATE_CONNECTED) == 0)
        {
            /* Stream socket must not be connected */
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_SocketShutdown_Impl(&token, Mode);

            if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
            {
                if (Mode & OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ)
                {
                    stream->stream_state &= ~OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE;
                }
                if (Mode & OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE)
                {
                    stream->stream_state &= ~OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE;
                }
            }
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
typedef enum
{
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_NONE           = 0, /**< @brief Reserved value, no effect */
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ      = 1, /**< @brief Disable future reading */
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE     = 2, /**< @brief Disable future writing */
    OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READWRITE = 3  /**< @brief Disable future reading or writing */
} OS_SocketShutdownMode_t
explanation:
I reviewed OS_SocketShutdown_Impl and the related definitions/caller. The fragments above are the locations where the validity/possible values of the Mode parameter affect control flow and therefore could cause unreachable branches (or conceal unreachable assumptions) and should be investigated for compliance with MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1.

Why other code fragments are not flagged:
- The retrieval of conn_impl via OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and the subsequent shutdown(conn_impl->fd, how) call are normal, directly reachable operations given a valid token; there is no compile-time or logic reason in the shown code that makes those statements unreachable.
- The assignments of return_code (OS_SUCCESS / OS_ERROR) based on the return of shutdown() are reachable depending on runtime return values and are not dead code.
- The OS_ObjectIdGetById/OS_ObjectIdRelease usage and the surrounding checks for socket_domain, socket_type, and stream_state are runtime conditional logic that can be taken or not depending on inputs/results; they are not statically unreachable from the provided code.
- There are no obvious unreachable constructs such as statements after a return, infinite loops without exit, or disabled conditional compilation blocks in the supplied code.

The selected fragments concentrate on the Mode validation/usage (enum definition, caller BUGCHECK, impl branching, and bitwise checks after the impl call) because these are the places where values may be constrained by the caller (or by BUGCHECK semantics) and could render some branches unreachable or inconsistent; they therefore warrant investigation to ensure no unreachable code exists.
